_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1. EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

1.1 STATIONARY SOURCE DESCRIPTION
The Cape Cod Ice East Providence facility utilizes anhydrous ammonia refrigeration to manufacture ice that is distributed throughout Massachusetts, Rhode Island, Connecticut, and parts of New Hampshire.  The facility also stores cranberries during the winter months.
 
Cape Cod Ice's facility is located at 1 Noyes Avenue, East Providence, Rhode Island (East Providence facility). The refrigeration system is located throughout the warehouse building of the East Providence facility with the piping located on the roof.

1.2 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES
Cape Cod Ice relies on written procedures and training to minimize accidental releases.  Every employee must complete awareness training and operating and maintenance training for their particular duties and responsibilities prior to working on any assignment. If any processes change, employees are retrained in the new process before working on an assignment.

Contractors are required to be properly trained in the safety programs before doing any work at
the facility.

All employees who operate, service, or maintain the ammonia refrigeration systems are trained to understand the safety and health hazards of the refrigerant and the refrigeration system at the facility. This knowledge is necessary for the protection of the individual, the other employees, and the community. All involved employees are trained in the following general topics:

Understanding how to read MSDS forms,
Knowing and understanding first aid for ammonia exposure,
Location and use of emergency equipment (eyewash, showers, and PPE),
Routine refrigeration system operation,
Emergency refrigeration system operation,
Emergency and normal refrigeration safety procedures, and
Individual's role in the emergency response plan.

Emergency Response Policy

In the event of an emergency, Cape Cod Ice personnel are expected to cooperate with fellow empl

oyees and
other support personnel to assure successful resolution of any emergency. Cape Cod Ice employees are
trained in emergency response for defensive measures only and rely on outside agencies to provide support
in responding to an emergency. Outside support is required for both fire response and response to an ammonia
release.

If an emergency situation develops at the facility:

Immediately report the problem to your supervisor, either by word of mouth or by phone. The supervisor is
responsible for contacting the Primary Emergency Response Coordinator. If a supervisor is not available or if
the situation requires immediate and obvious action, pull the Fire Alarm. Then contact the Primary
Emergency Response Coordinator immediately (508-642-8489). 

If you are able to report the problem to your supervisor, then your supervisor will contact the Primary
Emergency Response Coordinator immediately (508-642-8489).

The Primary Emergency Response Coordinator will notify the Local Fire Department and HAZMAT team
immediately.

Local Fire Department Emergency: 911
Non-Emergency: (401) 435-7600

RECCO HAZMAT 781-396-8780

The Emergency Response Coordinator, Local Fire Department, and HAZMAT team will assess the given
information and decide upon a course of action. The Primary Emergency Response Coordinator has the final
say in the decision.

The Fire Department and HAZMAT team shall notify the local emergency planning committee member (LEPC)
in the event that an off-site response or an off-site evacuation is needed.

LEPC Member (401) 435-7537

In the event an off-site response or an offsite evacuation is needed, the Emergency Response team shall
determine the wind direction to help Fire Department and HAZMAT team determine which direction the
plume is moving.

1.3 FACILTY LOCATION AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE
Cape Cod Ice is located at 1 Noyes Avenue in East Providence, Rhode Island in a residential area.

Cape Cod Ice stores one regul

fficient response in the event of an accidental
hazardous material release, fire or other emergency situation.

Cape Cod Ice personnel are expected to cooperate with fellow employees and other support personnel as
directed by the emergency response management to assure successful resolution of any emergency. Cape
Cod Ice employees are trained in emergency response for defensive measures only and rely on outside
agencies to provide support in responding to an emergency. Outside support is required for both fire response and
response to an ammonia release. Therefore, Cape Cod Ice is a non-responding facility and has
developed an Emergency Action Plan to ensure employees safety as required by the RMP regulation.

1.7 IMPROVEMENTS TO SAFETY

The following is a listed of suggested improvements in safety for Cape Cod Ice to make:

Install a ventilation system at the facility engine room.

Install emergency shutdown switches for the refrigeration systems that are either located outside of the
building and/or engine rooms.

Install windsocks that will be visible to emergency responders and evacuating personnel in the event of a
release at the facility.

Label all ammonia piping and valve systems properly at the facility.

ated substance on site above the threshold limitation, which is anhydrous
ammonia. The threshold limit for anhydrous ammonia is 10,000 lbs. Currently, the facility contains in its system an estimated 19,280 lbs. of anhydrous ammonia.

1.4 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION STEPS
The EPA's RMP prevention program includes the requirements of the OSHA PSM standards. Cape Cod Ice
currently has a Process Safety Management (PSM) program in place at the facility. The objective
of the PSM program is to prevent accidental chemical releases and minimize their impact if they do occur.
The focuses of the RMP and the PSM programs are to protect the employees and surrounding public. The
EPA requires twelve (12) of the fourteen (14) elements of the PSM to be included in the RMP. The
following twelve (12) elements are incorporated into the prevention programs for Cape Cod Ice:

o Process Safety Information
o Process Hazard Analysis (PHA)
o Operating Procedures
o Training
o Mechanical Integrity
o Management of Change
o Pre-Startup Review
o Compliance Audits
o Incident Investigation
o Employee Participation
o Hot Work Permit
o Contractors

1.5 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENTAL HISTORY
When an RMP is first submitted to the EPA, it must contain five-years of accident history. The five-year
history involves reporting any significant accidental releases of one or more of the regulated substances from
a covered process. All accident history reports for Cape Cod Ice are located in Appendix E-1 of the RMP.

1.6 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
It is the policy of the Cape Cod Ice facility management to implement the requirements of the
Emergency Action Plan by managing and operating the facility in accordance with applicable
regulations and general good operating practices. The objective is to minimize the risk of a fire, or an
accidental hazardous material release, including anhydrous ammonia.  Cape Cod Ice management has
developed the Emergency Action Plan to ensure a fast and e
